__data__.text: Glenn Youngkin was sworn in as the Governor of Virginia on January 15, 2022.
Winsome Sears was elected as the Lieutenant Governor of Virginia and is the first woman of color to hold a statewide office in Virginia.
Jason Miyares was elected as the Attorney General of Virginia and is the first Latino to hold a statewide office in Virginia.
The Washington Post called the Republican ticket of Youngkin, Sears, and Miyares "historically diverse".
The Washington Post reported that the election of the diverse Republican ticket was a sign of "inroads" made by the Republican Party "in the African American and Latino communities."
Douglas Wilder, a former Democratic Governor of Virginia, commented that Republicans had "one-upped" Democrats with the historic achievement.
Wilder also said that the achievement showed that Democrats "can't take the [Black] community for granted."
Youngkin's inauguration took place two years into the COVID-19 pandemic.
Youngkin's first week in office coincided with the January 14–17, 2022 North American winter storm.
On the morning of his inauguration, Youngkin participated in a community service project at the Reconciliation Statue along the Richmond Slave Trail in Shockoe Bottom.
Shockoe Bottom was the second largest domestic slave market in the United States before the Civil War.
An inauguration eve party was held for Youngkin at the Omni Richmond Hotel.
Another inauguration eve event for Youngkin was later held at the Science Museum of Virginia.
On the night of his inauguration, Youngkin held a celebratory event at the Richmond Main Street Station.
The Washington Post wrote that Youngkin's inaugural address "delivered the blend of religious confidence and boardroom bravado that powered his victory".
The Associated Press characterized Youngkin's address as one that carried "a tone of bipartisanship and optimism".
Youngkin used the address to criticize modern politics as "too toxic".
Immediately after the address, Youngkin "stirred partisan rancor" by
Glenn Youngkin, the Governor of Virginia, has been criticized by the Virginia Legislative Black Caucus for his stance on critical race theory.
The Richmond Times-Dispatch reported that Youngkin's stance on critical race theory has alarmed many educators in Virginia.
Critics of Youngkin view the banning of critical race theory as an attempt to "whitewash" history and "erase black history".
On his first day in office, Youngkin signed executive actions that rescinded COVID-19 regulations enacted by the previous administration.
One of these executive actions rescinded Virginia's statewide mask mandate for public schools and made compliance with local public school mask mandates optional.
Another executive action rescinded the COVID-19 vaccine mandate for all state employees.
Youngkin's first day in office also saw an executive order calling for a reevaluation of the workplace safety standards adopted by the Northam administration as a protection against COVID-19.
Youngkin's other executive actions on his first day in office included firing and replacing the entire Virginia Parole Board.
He also called for the state's Attorney General to investigate the handling of sexual assaults in the Loudoun County public school system.
Youngkin initiated reviews of the Virginia Parole Board, the Virginia Department of Motor Vehicles, and the Virginia Employment Commission.
He created commissions to combat antisemitism and human trafficking.
Youngkin ordered state agencies under his authority to reduce nonmandatory regulations by 25%.
He called for the state to reevaluate its membership in the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative.
The Washington Post noted that Youngkin's first executive orders went beyond the practice of his predecessors in the Executive Mansion over the past 20 years.
Each of Youngkin's predecessors focused their first executive actions on less incendiary topics, such as anti-discrimination protections and policy studies.
Youngkin's first executive actions, however, "poked a stick directly into a host of polarizing issues".
Former Lieutenant Governor of Virginia Bill Bolling, a Republican, condemned Youngkin's repeal of public school mask mand
The Chesapeake lawsuit was dismissed on the same day that the Youngkin administration joined a lawsuit against the Loudoun County school system.
The lawsuit against the Loudoun County school system was brought by a group of parents who were challenging the school system's decision to continue enforcing a mask mandate.
School systems in Virginia began dropping their mask mandates in mid-February after Youngkin signed a bill requiring them to do so by March 1.
The ACLU expanded the scope of its lawsuit against the Youngkin administration to include the new law.
On March 23, 2022, a federal judge decided the lawsuit by ruling that school districts in Virginia could choose to require masking in areas frequented by the plaintiffs.
The ruling did not overturn Youngkin's executive order or the state law and only applies to school systems attended by the plaintiffs.
Following an appeal by the Youngkin administration, a settlement was reached in December 2022.
The settlement allows mask mandates under similar terms to those established by the March court ruling.
Glenn Youngkin began announcing nominations for his sixteen-member cabinet on December 20, 2021, and did not finish the process until after his inauguration.
The Washington Post noted that Youngkin assembled his cabinet at a slower pace than prior Virginia governors.
Youngkin suggested while campaigning for the Republican gubernatorial nomination that he would name Kirk Cox to the position of Secretary of Education.
However, Youngkin instead chose Aimee Rogstad Guidera as his Secretary of Education.
Five of Youngkin's cabinet nominees are women.
Three of Youngkin's cabinet nominees are African American.
Many of his nominees were brought in from other states.
Only a few of his nominees had any prior government experience.
The Washington Post noted that the newcomer status of Youngkin's nominees presents the new administration with a steep learning curve.
Four of Youngkin's cabinet nominees served under previous Virginia governors.
Youngkin's Secretary of the Commonwealth nominee
Glenn Youngkin, a person, was inaugurated as the Governor of Virginia on January 15, 2022.
Daniel Gade, a person, was named by Youngkin as commissioner of Virginia's Department of Veterans Services.
Craig Crenshaw, a person, will serve under Youngkin as Secretary of Veterans Affairs.
Jeff Goettman, a person, served as a Treasury Department official in the Trump administration and was chosen by Youngkin to serve as chief of staff.
Richard Cullen, a person, was chosen by Youngkin to serve as counselor, a cabinet-level position.
The Washington Post described Cullen as "the ultimate Richmond insider".
Cullen had been a chairman of McGuireWoods.
In the 1990s, Cullen served out the remainder of Jim Gilmore's term as Attorney General of Virginia.
The Washington Post theorized that Cullen's appointment could suggest that Youngkin does not intend to thoroughly disrupt 'politics as usual' in Virginia.
Youngkin's immediate predecessor, Ralph Northam, served as Governor of Virginia before Youngkin.
Northam established the position of Chief Diversity Officer in response to a scandal involving racist imagery appearing on Northam's medical school yearbook page.
The idea for a Chief Diversity Officer was born out of a commitment made by Northam to focus the remainder of his term on advancing racial equity in Virginia.
Youngkin did not announce a nomination for Chief Diversity Officer until after his inauguration.
Youngkin's nominee for Chief Diversity Officer, Angela Sailor, was an executive at the Heritage Foundation.
Sailor held multiple roles in George W. Bush's presidential administration.
Virginia's Chief Diversity Officer oversees the state's Office of Diversity, Equity and Inclusion.
Upon announcing Sailor's nomination to serve in his cabinet, Youngkin issued an executive order restructuring the agency.
The agency would "be an ambassador for unborn children" according to Youngkin's executive order.
Wheeler served as acting Secretary of Natural Resources until mid-March 2022.
Youngkin appointed Wheeler as a senior advisor in mid-March 2022.
The role of senior advisor does not require confirmation by the legislature.
In June of the same year, Youngkin appointed Wheeler to direct the Office of Regulatory Management.
The Office of Regulatory Management was newly established by Youngkin through executive order.
The purpose of the Office of Regulatory Management is to reduce state regulatory requirements.
Wheeler was able to assume his role at the Office of Regulatory Management without legislative approval.
Republicans in the Virginia House of Delegates blocked the reappointment of a judge to the State Corporation Commission.
Two Virginia Supreme Court vacancies were left open by House Republicans.
This action was taken in retaliation against Democrats for opposing Wheeler's nomination.
Wheeler's nomination to serve as Secretary of Natural Resources was defeated in the State Senate.
House Republicans, with Youngkin's support, announced plans to reject about 1,000 appointees to state boards.
The appointees had been nominated by Northam.
It was a long-standing custom in Virginia politics for an outgoing governor's nominees to be confirmed with bipartisan support.
Many of the nominees had already been serving in their positions for several months.
After Democrats responded by threatening to reject all future appointments made by Youngkin, Republicans scaled back their plan.
Republicans rejected only eleven of Northam's nominees.

The rejected nominees had been appointed to the Virginia State Board of Education, the State Air Pollution Control Board, the State Water Control Board, the Virginia Safety and Health Codes Board, and the Virginia Marine Resources Commission.

According to Republican leadership in the Virginia House of Delegates, vacancies were created on these specific boards so that Youngkin would have greater influence over boards related to his main policy priorities.
Democrats retaliated in turn by rejecting four of Youngkin's five nominees to the Virginia Parole Board
In June 2022, Taylor Moran, a publication's staff writer, started a new role as Glenn Youngkin's full-time senior political adviser.
Aubrey Layne served as Secretary of Finance in the Ralph Northam administration.
Aubrey Layne has been an unpaid advisor to Glenn Youngkin, serving while working as an executive at Sentara Healthcare.
Richard Cullen, Glenn Youngkin's counselor, has determined that Layne and Moran's roles in the administration comply with state ethics rules.
Glenn Youngkin describes himself as "pro-life" but supports legal access to abortion in cases of rape, incest, or protecting the mother's life.
During his gubernatorial campaign, Glenn Youngkin criticized the Texas Heartbeat Act, which bans abortions around the sixth week of pregnancy.
In July 2021, while running for governor, Glenn Youngkin stated his preference for a "pain threshold bill", which bans abortion at around twenty weeks.
Glenn Youngkin introduced a failed amendment to the state budget that aimed to ban the state government from funding abortion services in cases of severe fetal abnormalities.
Glenn Youngkin claimed that this amendment would have made Virginia's policy on the public funding of abortion services consistent with the federal Hyde Amendment.

In May 2022, Glenn Youngkin joined Maryland Governor Larry Hogan in calling on the federal government to intervene against peaceful protests targeting the homes of conservative Supreme Court Justices living in Virginia and Maryland.
Glenn Youngkin described these abortion rights protests as not appropriate nor legal at the residences of justices.
Glenn Youngkin was criticized by some conservatives for seeking federal action instead of enforcing a state law that bars protesters from targeting private residences.
The state law banning protests at private residences was dismissed as "weak" by Glenn Youngkin.
The Washington Post described the state law's constitutionality as unclear.
Glenn Youngkin and Hogan believed the protests violated a federal law that forbids demonstrations intended to sway judges on pending cases.
Glenn Youngkin, while running for governor, proposed a ban on abortion in Virginia after 15 weeks of pregnancy.
The proposed abortion ban by Youngkin would include exceptions for rape, incest, or protecting the mother's life.
Youngkin supports the COVID-19 vaccination effort.
Youngkin and his family are vaccinated against COVID-19.
Youngkin opposes mask and vaccine mandates.
In his first address to the General Assembly, Youngkin encouraged Virginians to get the COVID-19 vaccine.
Youngkin challenged the Biden administration's employer vaccine mandate.
Youngkin co-signed a letter with West Virginia Governor Jim Justice, asking the Biden administration to exempt rural and state-run hospitals from the vaccine mandate.
Youngkin opposes adding the COVID-19 vaccine to the list of required immunizations for school children.
While running for governor, Youngkin said that he would model his public school mask policy after that of Florida Governor Ron DeSantis.
Youngkin's initial mask policy proposal would ban local school boards from implementing their own mask mandates.
Youngkin later reversed his position, saying that he would give local school boards the discretion to implement their own mask policies.
After winning the election, Youngkin re-emphasized his intention to repeal the statewide mask mandate while still allowing for local mandates.
On his first day in office, Youngkin signed an executive order that both repealed the statewide mask mandate and attempted to nullify any local mandates.
The executive order was challenged by two lawsuits contending that it was in violation of state law at the time and exceeded Youngkin's constitutional authority.
On February 16, 2022, Youngkin signed a bill that made masking optional in all public schools throughout Virginia.
The ACLU filed a lawsuit against the Youngkin administration, arguing that the mask mandate ban was discriminatory against medically vulnerable students.
The lawsuit was decided on March 23, in a ruling that maintains Youngkin's ban on school mask mandates except for in areas frequented by students represented in the lawsuit.
On February 16, 2022, Glenn Youngkin, the Governor of Virginia, convened the Virginia Department of Labor and Industry's Safety and Health Codes Board.
The board voted on whether to revoke COVID-19 workplace safety standards.
A few days before the vote, House Republicans rejected the nominations of two members appointed to the board by Governor Ralph Northam.
Both members were expected to vote against revoking the safety standards.
Their nominations were rejected as part of a larger process of expelling Northam appointees from several state boards.
The remaining members of the Safety and Health Codes Board voted 7 to 3 in favor of recommending that the safety standards be revoked.
Following a public comment period, the board reconvened on March 21 and voted to officially revoke the safety standards.
Virginia had been the first state to adopt workplace safety standards in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.
The standards, which included a mask mandate for workers in high-risk indoor areas, officially ended on March 23, 2022.
Upon taking office, Youngkin extended a limited state of emergency that had been implemented by the Northam administration.
The extension was originally set to last until February 21, 2022 but was renewed through March 22 of that year.
In January 2022, the Virginia Department of Health, under Youngkin's authority, became one of the first states to cease efforts at contact tracing every positive case of COVID-19.
Health officials with the department explained that the decision was made primarily due to the increased difficulty of contact tracing the omicron variant.
These officials further explained that the policy would allow the department to better focus its resources on responding to "outbreaks and cases in high risk settings".
Individuals who test positive should continue to personally notify contacts.
In May 2022, Youngkin announced that on July 5 of that year, he would be scaling back the telework policy for Virginia's executive branch employees.
Under Youngkin's policy, those employees can telework one day a week or on a temporary basis with
The Washington Post reported that, before an amendment was enacted, law enforcement in Virginia typically used their discretion to deny access to almost all of their files to all requesters.
The amendment, which was enacted in 2022, restored discretion to law enforcement over whether to release files pertaining to closed investigations.
The amendment requires that access to such files be granted to the families of victims and to attorneys working on post-conviction proceedings.

If law enforcement chooses to fulfill any other request for access to files pertaining to closed investigations, they can do so only after victims involved in the investigation have been notified and given a chance to object.
Any victim who objects can then file for an injunction, at which point a judge would determine the outcome of the request.
Glenn Youngkin, the Governor of Virginia, signed the aforementioned amendment.
Youngkin's reform of Virginia's Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) law gained some bipartisan support in the Virginia legislature.
The Innocence Project opposed Youngkin's FOIA reform.
In March 2022, Youngkin vetoed a bipartisan bill that would have shifted authority for hiring a local auditor of police misconduct in Arlington County from the County Manager to the County Board.
The auditor would be tasked with working alongside a civilian oversight board that Arlington County had established one year earlier in response to the racial justice protests of 2020.
As a Dillon Rule state, Virginia localities require approval from the state government to make decisions over any matter that state law has not explicitly given them control over.

The Arlington County Board had wanted authority for hiring the auditor, so as to ensure the position's independence from local law enforcement, which is overseen by the County Manager, who also hires the county's police chief.
The Washington Post described the vetoed legislation as "esoteric but noteworthy".
Youngkin's veto appeared to tie the bill to much broader debates over how local governments should scrutinize police.
Youngkin's veto was largely inspired by his displeasure with the civilian overs

The Virginia Police Benevolent Association proposed a bill that states the number of arrests made or summonses issued by a law-enforcement officer should not be the sole criterion for evaluating job performance.
Both parties in the Virginia state legislature supported the bill.
An original provision of the bill allowed for violations of its bans to be investigated by the FBI, but this provision was removed from the final bill.
Glenn Youngkin, the Governor of Virginia, introduced an amendment to the 2022 state budget that limited the number of inmates who could qualify for an expanded early release program.
The early release program allows inmates in Virginia to earn time off their sentences through good behavior credits.
The program had been expanded through legislation signed in 2020 by Youngkin's predecessor, Ralph Northam.
The expansion of the program raised the cap on how many good behavior credits could be earned for most inmates.
The expanded program allowed inmates convicted of violent crimes to reduce any concurrent or consecutive sentences that had been imposed for nonviolent crimes.
Youngkin and other Republicans characterized this aspect of the program as an unintentional loophole.

Democrats largely disagreed with this characterization, arguing that the expanded program had been intentionally designed to give violent offenders the ability to reduce sentences unrelated to violent offenses.
Youngkin's amendment made inmates convicted of violent crimes fully ineligible for the expanded program.
The amendment prevented inmates from using the newly available credits to reduce any sentences.
The expanded early release program was approved by Northam in 2020, but it did not take effect until July 1, 2022.
About 550 inmates convicted of violent crimes were set to be released once the law took effect in July 2022.
Youngkin's amendment was approved a few weeks before these inmates would have been released.
As a result, these inmates were not released at that time, even though they had already been told of their planned release.
During his campaign for governor, Youngkin frequently said that Virginia's economy was "in the ditch".
In late August 2021, Glenn Youngkin announced a series of tax cut proposals.
The Associated Press called these proposals "the most wide-ranging and detailed look at the priorities of a potential Youngkin administration".
If enacted in full, the tax cut proposals would have amounted to $1.8 billion in one-time tax cuts and $1.4 billion in recurring tax cuts.
Youngkin proposed paying for much of his proposed tax cuts with the state's budget surplus.
At the time, the budget surplus was projected to total $2.6 billion.
The Washington Post and NPR noted that much of the revenue would be unavailable for tax cuts.
State law required that over half of the amount be devoted to the state's "rainy day" reserve fund, water quality improvement fund, and transportation fund.
Virginia's budget surplus continued to grow.
By the end of Northam's term, the budget surplus was projected to total at least $13.4 billion for the state's then-upcoming budget cycle.
Glenn Youngkin hired Stephen Moore as his campaign's senior economic advisor.
Stephen Moore had helped oversee significant tax cuts in Kansas several years earlier.
Sam Brownback was the governor of Kansas when Moore overseen the tax cuts.
NPR noted that Youngkin "sourced much of his fiscal agenda from [Moore]."
The Brownback tax cuts are widely seen as a failure.
The tax cuts led to the state slashing spending for priorities such as education and transportation when revenue dried up.
The tax cuts were ultimately repealed on a bipartisan vote.
Glenn Youngkin's Democratic gubernatorial opponent was Terry McAuliffe.
McAuliffe cited the economic downturn in Kansas as a way to critique Youngkin's economic platform.
Moore acknowledged that the Brownback tax cuts had negatively impacted the Kansas economy.
Moore argued that the tax cuts should be perceived as an anomaly.
He claimed that several other states "did really well when they lowered taxes".
In
The Richmond-Times Dispatch described a policy as a longtime Democratic priority.
Republicans had opposed this policy.
The policy was included in the budget as a compromise between the two parties.
Glenn Youngkin, a governor, had a goal of offering relief from the state's gas tax.
The legislature blocked Youngkin's gas tax relief goal along mostly party lines.
Democrats argued that Youngkin's gas tax holiday proposal would have deprived the state of revenue for transportation projects while offering insufficient relief to consumers.
WVTF, a Virginia NPR affiliate, estimated that about one-third of the savings from Youngkin's gas tax holiday proposal would have been kept by the oil industry.
WVTF also estimated that about one-quarter of the savings would have gone to out-of-state drivers.
Youngkin acknowledged that his proposal may not have resulted in significant savings for Virginians.
Youngkin opposed a Democratic counter proposal to send direct payments to Virginia car owners.
Both WTOP and WRIC estimated that Youngkin's proposal for suspending the gas tax would have decreased funding for Virginia transportation projects by about $400 million.
During the 2022 legislative session, Youngkin failed to enact a proposal of his.

The proposal would have required Virginia localities with rising real estate values to either gain approval through public referendums for any increases in revenue resulting from local real estate taxes or else lower their local real estate tax rates.
The Youngkin administration described this proposal as "a pillar" of its tax plan.
Although the budget signed by Youngkin in 2022 passed with bipartisan support, it was opposed by several Democrats.

Democrats argued that too much of the state's record surplus was spent on tax cuts at the expense of funding for affordable housing, mental health services, gun violence prevention, and transportation.
Affordable housing and tenant protections were included in the state budget signed by Youngkin in 2022.
The budget included a $150 million investment in the Virginia Housing Trust Fund.
This amounted to half the total Northam had proposed investing in the fund
Glenn Youngkin, a candidate for governor, has expressed support for repealing collective bargaining rights for public employees and the requirement for project labor agreements on public works.
Education was a central focus of Youngkin's campaign, with the candidate holding Parents Matter rallies to mobilize voters on the issue.
The New York Times reported that Youngkin's campaign turned Virginia public schools into a "cultural war zone."
Youngkin spoke against what he characterized as the pervasive teaching of critical race theory in Virginia schools.
Politifact found no evidence of critical race theory in state curriculum standards and little evidence of it being taught in classrooms.
Critics have noted that Youngkin sent his own children to private schools where resources promoting critical race theory have been recommended.
Youngkin served on the governing board for one of those schools from 2016 until 2019, but has distanced himself from anti-racism initiatives adopted by the school.
The Loudoun County school system was identified as "ground zero" for Youngkin's victory due to widespread activism among parents who opposed progressive school policies.
Following two sexual assaults in Loudoun County schools, Youngkin called for campus police to be stationed at every school in Virginia.
After winning the election, Youngkin directed the state's Attorney General, Jason Miyares, to investigate the Loudoun County school system's handling of the assaults.
The perpetrator of the assaults was initially characterized as gender fluid, but this was later denied by the perpetrator's lawyer.
Conservative media coverage focused on the gender fluidity aspect of the assaults, fueling opposition to bathroom policies accommodating transgender students.
Youngkin's Democratic opponent, Terry McAuliffe, claimed that the assaults were being exploited as a "transphobic dog whistle" during the campaign.
A major subject of opposition among Republicans during the campaign was a state law signed in 2020 by Youngkin's predecessor, Ralph Northam, requiring protections for transgender students.
Youngkin has been critical of these protections and supported teachers who refused to refer to their students by preferred pronouns.
Youngkin
The Virginian-Pilot published criticism stating that the Virginia Math Pathways Initiative was a "dumbing down of standards".
Glenn Youngkin, a politician, referred to the Virginia Math Pathways Initiative as a "left-wing takeover of public education".
Conservatives, including Youngkin, claimed that the Virginia Math Pathways Initiative would eliminate advanced high school math classes.
James Lane, who was Virginia's Superintendent at the time, and NPR, disputed the claim that the Virginia Math Pathways Initiative would eliminate advanced math classes.
The Virginia Math Pathways Initiative would prioritize data science and data analytics over calculus while still offering students the opportunity to enroll in calculus at an accelerated pace.
Education officials within the Northam administration explored the potential benefits of detracking students prior to the 11th grade, but no plans to do so were ever adopted.
In April 2021, education officials explained that the Virginia Math Pathways Initiative was not designed to eliminate advanced math classes at any grade level.
The Washington Post reported that the actual nature of the Virginia Math Pathways Initiative had been obscured by prominent Virginians and right-wing news outlets.
In early April 2022, Youngkin signed a bill allowing school parents throughout Virginia to review and opt their children out of any educational material containing "sexually explicit content".
Alternative material will be provided for opted out students.
This is the first statewide law in the nation allowing for parental review of sexually explicit content in school curriculum.
Democrats have criticized the bill for taking control over education away from local school systems.
Democrats have argued that the bill's definition of "sexually explicit content" is "overly broad".
The bill passed along mostly party lines.
A similar bill, known as the "Beloved Bill", was vetoed by McAuliffe in both 2016 and 2017.
The "Beloved Bill" became a focal point of Virginia's 2021 gubernatorial election.
Reviving the bill was identified by The Washington Post as "one of the key promises"
Youngkin signed a bill that has been argued to have no legal impact as it largely reiterates existing federal law.
Youngkin's administration set up an email tipline for reports about what he characterized as "divisive practices" in Virginia schools.
The tipline was announced in a news release focused on Youngkin's executive order banning school mask mandates.
Youngkin discussed the tipline on a conservative radio show, encouraging parents to report any instances where they feel that their fundamental rights are being violated.
Youngkin's administration would "catalogue it all" and begin "rooting it out".
The Washington Post reported that the tipline was part of a broader push by Youngkin to identify and root out what he says are elements of critical race theory in the state’s curriculum.
Critics of the tipline viewed it as divisive, authoritarian and unfairly targeting educators.
Virginia Republicans defended the tipline by comparing it to systems that previous governors of the state had set up for people to report violations of business regulations and health protocols.
CNN reported that the initiative had drawn national attention.
Colin Jost derided the tipline on Saturday Night Live during Weekend Update.
John Legend encouraged opponents of the initiative to co-opt the tipline, tweeting, "Black parents need to flood these tip lines with complaints about our history being silenced."
Critics of Youngkin were spamming the tipline.
Larry Sabato predicted that the tipline would "backfire" on Youngkin.

Virginia teachers and the Virginia Education Association criticized the tipline for targeting teachers who are already struggling amid staffing shortages and other challenges related to the COVID-19 pandemic.
The Lead with Jake Tapper reported that the tipline could cause retention problems among Virginia educators.
Youngkin's administration responded to complaints submitted to the tipline.
The Virginian-Pilot made multiple inquiries about how complaints sent to the tipline would be used by the Youngkin administration, but these inquiries went unanswered.
FOIA requests to see emails sent
The Youngkin administration reached a settlement in a lawsuit.
The Youngkin administration closed down a tipline in September.
The Washington Post reported that the tipline was closed down because tips had dried up.
A second lawsuit involving the Youngkin administration is ongoing.
During Virginia's 2022 legislative session, the Youngkin administration proposed an amendment concerning elections for the Loudoun County School Board.
The proposed amendment would have caused elections to be held a year in advance for seven of the board's nine members.
A spokesperson for Youngkin described the amendment as an attempt at holding the Loudoun County School Board accountable.
Opposing the Loudoun County School Board over a variety of issues had been a major focus of Youngkin's gubernatorial campaign.
Democrats, several political scientists, and the county school board itself charged that Youngkin was attempting to subvert the election results that had placed the board members in office.
The Washington Post reported that the amendment was an intrusion into local election integrity without modern precedent in Virginia.

The Washington Post reported that the amendment was one of the more controversial actions taken by Youngkin and led to one of the harshest partisan eruptions in the Virginia state legislature since the start of Youngkin's term.
Legal scholar A.E. Dick Howard argued that the amendment was likely in violation of Virginia's Constitution.
The proposed amendment passed in the Republican-controlled House of Delegates but was defeated in the Democratic-controlled State Senate.
In September 2022, the Youngkin administration announced that it would be repealing protections for transgender students in Virginia schools.
These protections had been established through a bipartisan bill signed by Northam in 2020.
That bill requires that policies pertaining to transgender students be in compliance throughout all school districts with model policies developed by the Virginia Department of Education.
Under Northam, these model policies had mandated that students be allowed access to school facilities and nonathletic school programs corresponding with their gender identity.
The policies deferred to the Virginia High School League in matters pertaining to trans
The Youngkin administration announced replacement policies for the treatment of transgender students in Virginia school districts.

Most Virginia school districts had not adopted the Northam administration's model policies regarding transgender students by the time the Youngkin administration's replacement policies were announced.
Some school districts have refused to adopt the Youngkin administration's model policies, stating that they are in violation of state law.

Legal scholars and Democratic politicians argue that Youngkin's model policies may be in violation of Virginia law because they fail to meet the criteria of addressing common issues regarding transgender students in accordance with evidence-based best practices and protecting transgender students from bullying and harassment.
Youngkin's model policies may also be in violation of the Virginia Human Rights Act, which bans schools from discriminating on the basis of gender identity.
A policy mandating that students use restrooms corresponding with their biological sex may be unenforceable due to a 2020 court ruling in G.G. v. Gloucester County School Board.
Shortly after the Youngkin administration's policies were announced, several thousand students from over ninety Virginia schools protested by engaging in walkouts.
Organizers of the walkouts stated that the policies will only hurt students and are a cruel attempt to politicize the existence of LGBTQIA+ students for political gain.
Both Youngkin and McAuliffe campaigned on increasing the education budget in Virginia.
Outgoing governor Ralph Northam proposed increasing Virginia's biennual education budget from $14.8 billion to $17.2 billion.
McAuliffe's platform called for increasing the state's spending on education by $2 billion annually.
Youngkin did not begin sharing proposals for state spending on education until months after securing the Republican nomination.
Youngkin's education platform was criticized for being far lighter on details than McAuliffe's and for largely focusing on cultural issues over budgetary proposals.

Youngkin began offering specific proposals for education spending late in the summer of 2021, including $100 million a year for raising teacher salaries, $200 million for improvements to school infrastructure, and over $1 billion for expanding school choice programs.
Youngkin
The 2022 biennial state budget includes one-time $1,000 bonuses for teachers.
This plan was chosen over a different plan preferred by Republicans.
The alternative plan would have provided a 8% salary increase for teachers over two years and 1% bonuses.
The 2022 biennial state budget allotted $1.25 billion for school construction and maintenance.
This amount is more than what had been proposed in Northam's outgoing budget.
However, $1.25 billion is a small fraction of the $25 billion needed to fully replace the state's oldest schools.
The Virginia Preschool Initiative was expanded by the 2022 biennial state budget.
This program provides preschool for many low-income children in the state.
Before 2022, the program only served children aged four or older.
Only families earning less than the federal poverty line could qualify.
The 2022 state budget lowered the age eligibility to include three year olds.
The income threshold was raised to 300% of the federal poverty line.
In September 2022, Youngkin issued an executive order to combat Virginia's teacher shortages.

The order aims to fill vacancies by recruiting retired teachers, people whose teaching licenses have expired, people with out-of-state teaching licenses, college students in teacher training programs, and military veterans seeking to transition into teaching careers.
The order provides additional funding to school districts with the most severe teacher shortages in Virginia.
The order seeks to bolster in-school child care options for teachers.
The Washington Post reported that Youngkin's actions to loosen standards for becoming a teacher are similar to efforts in other states.
The Washington Post reported that some educator groups in Virginia have criticized aspects of Youngkin's executive order.
Education policy experts have argued that teacher shortages have been exacerbated in Virginia by education-related culture war issues.
Youngkin supports expanding charter schools in the state.
Youngkin's actual goal for char
Glenn Youngkin has advocated for allowing private businesses to enter into lab school partnerships.
Youngkin supports legislation that would give substantial preference to lab school applications filed by historically black colleges or universities.
The same preference would be given to applications seeking to establish lab schools in underserved communities.

Youngkin supports revising how Virginia public schools are funded, so that per pupil funding for any students attending lab schools in the state would go to the institutions operating the schools attended by those students.
An amendment proposed by Youngkin for the 2022 state budget would have enacted this plan but was not adopted by the General Assembly.
The Virginia Education Association and The Free Lance–Star have both supported Youngkin's goal of re-establishing lab schools in Virginia.
They have criticized Youngkin's plan for redirecting per pupil funding away from local school boards.
Because Virginia law allows lab schools to enroll students from anywhere in the state, the plan could lead to decreased funding for certain school districts.
In 2022, Youngkin signed legislation allowing college athletes in Virginia to profit through name, image, and likeness deals.
This legislation permanently codified a policy that had already been enacted on a temporary basis a year earlier when Northam was in office.
The policy does not allow college athletes to sponsor or endorse alcohol, tobacco, marijuana, drugs, weapons, casinos, or adult entertainment.
The policy allows student athletes to hire agents and ensures that scholarships cannot be lost as a result of earning compensation through a name, image, and likeness deal.
In April 2022, Youngkin signed House Bill 741 into law mandating all public schools in Virginia to create detailed digital floor plans of their buildings.
The law provides $6.5 million to schools to create these floor plans.
In May 2022, Youngkin signed a bipartisan bill requiring that principals report to law enforcement certain misdemeanor crimes committed by students on school grounds.
This restores a law that had existed before the Northam administration.

Glenn Youngkin, the Governor of Virginia, called for Virginia to become a world leader in nuclear energy.
Youngkin proposed building a small modular reactor in Southwest Virginia within the next decade.
After winning the election, Youngkin said that he would use an executive action to withdraw Virginia from the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative.
Youngkin referred to the initiative as a "carbon tax".
Leaving the initiative would save ratepayers an average of about $50 a year, according to Youngkin.
Democrats argued that leaving the initiative would cut off a source of revenue for the state that raises hundreds of millions of dollars a year.
This revenue is used for flood control and to provide low income ratepayers with energy assistance.
On his first day in office, Youngkin signed an executive order calling for a reevaluation of Virginia's membership in the initiative.
The Washington Post noted that Youngkin may lack the legal authority to withdraw from the initiative without legislative approval.
The publication theorized that this legal limitation may have been why Youngkin ultimately ordered a reevaluation of the initiative rather than a withdrawal.
In August 2022, the Youngkin administration announced that it would attempt to withdraw Virginia from the initiative by the end of 2023 without seeking legislative approval to do so.
Youngkin also announced his desire to block a law set to take effect in 2024, which would require that Virginia follow California's vehicle emissions standards.
In his 2022 address to the General Assembly, Youngkin called for the state to better protect against pollution of the James River.
Youngkin voiced support for ongoing efforts to clean the Chesapeake Bay.
The Governor proposed that the state establish a Coastal Virginia Resiliency Authority to combat rising sea levels.
Later that year, Youngkin opposed the scope of a bill that had been designed to improve Virginia's flood preparedness.
Youngkin attempted to "gut" the bill by amending it but was overruled by a unanimous vote by the State Senate.
In April 2022, Youngkin issued an executive order that rescinded former governor Ralph North
The Virginia Public Access Project (VPM) reported that Republicans cited a specific decision as a reason for transferring permitting authority away from citizen review boards.
Glenn Youngkin, the governor of Virginia, proposed legislation to revise the permitting process. This legislation gained some bipartisan support in the state legislature.
Environmental groups opposed Youngkin's permitting process legislation.
In 2022, Youngkin vetoed a bill that would have set a three-year statute of limitations on the collection of medical debt.
The medical debt bill had passed the state legislature with broad bipartisan support.
Youngkin explained his veto of the medical debt bill by claiming that such a policy would have caused higher costs for consumers.
The Washington Post noted that this claim conflicted with national studies showing that the policy would have decreased costs for consumers.
Youngkin vetoed a bill prohibiting health insurance companies from charging higher premiums for tobacco use.
The tobacco use bill had also passed the state legislature with broad bipartisan support.
The Washington Post noted that Youngkin's veto of the tobacco use bill was in opposition to "the unanimous recommendation of a bipartisan study commission".
Youngkin introduced an amendment to the 2022 state budget that took $10 million over two years from financial aid for undocumented immigrants pursuing higher education in Virginia.
The amendment used the money instead to increase financial aid for students attending Virginia's historically black colleges and universities.
The amendment was passed by the General Assembly along mostly party lines.
Half of the money reallocated by the amendment will be used to supplement in-state student aid at Norfolk State and Virginia State universities.
The other half of the money will be used to increase Virginia Tuition Assistance Grants for students enrolled in historically Black institutions.
Lamont Bagby, chair of the Virginia Legislative Black Caucus, condemned the amendment.
Several Democrats characterized the amendment as an effort to "pit" two different disadvantaged student groups against each other.

Glenn Youngkin, the Governor of Virginia, stated that he cannot live in the world of hypotheticals.
The Virginia Constitution includes an amendment that bans same-sex marriage.
According to the Washington Post, this amendment would become operative again if the Supreme Court reverses its decision.
In Youngkin's first year in office, an effort to repeal the amendment banning same-sex marriage was defeated by Republicans.
Youngkin proposed to recriminalize possessing more than two ounces of marijuana in Virginia.
Previously, possessing between one ounce and one pound of marijuana was punishable by a $25 fine.

Youngkin's proposal to introduce misdemeanor penalties for possessing over the legal amount of marijuana was inspired by a recommendation made in 2021 by the state legislature's nonpartisan Joint Legislative Audit and Review Commission.
Under Youngkin's proposal, possessing more than two ounces of marijuana would become a Class 2 misdemeanor.
Possessing more than six ounces of marijuana would become a Class 1 misdemeanor under Youngkin's proposal.
During the 2022 legislative session, the Democratic-controlled State Senate passed a bill that would have made possessing more than four ounces of marijuana a Class 3 misdemeanor.
This bill was rejected by the Republican-controlled House of Delegates.
In 2022, Virginia made possessing between four ounces and a pound of marijuana in public a Class 3 misdemeanor for a first-time offense and a Class 2 misdemeanor for repeat offenses.
This change was part of a bipartisan budget deal signed by Youngkin.
The same budget deal banned the sale of cannabis products shaped as animals, humans, vehicles, or fruits.
This ban was implemented to protect against accidental consumption by children.
In 2022, Youngkin signed legislation allowing patients to purchase medical marijuana immediately upon receiving a certificate to do so from a registered medical provider.

The Washington Post wrote that Glenn Youngkin demonstrated uncommon flexibility on the issue of endorsing conspiracy theorists within his own party.
Some moderate Republicans, such as Liz Cheney, David Jolly, and Bill Kristol, have criticized Glenn Youngkin for refusing to distance himself from conspiracy theorists within his own party.
Glenn Youngkin campaigned for former Maine governor Paul LePage during the midterms.
Paul LePage, during his previous tenure as governor, made comments that were condemned as racist by both Republican and Democratic politicians.
Paul LePage's racist comments included a statement where he referred to people of color or people of Hispanic origin as "the enemy."
Glenn Youngkin initially claimed to be unaware of Paul LePage's racist comments.
Glenn Youngkin later condemned Paul LePage's racist comments.
Glenn Youngkin defended his choice to campaign for Paul LePage by stating that Paul LePage had apologized for his comments.
According to The Washington Post, Paul LePage had not actually apologized for most of his racist comments.
Nancy Pelosi's husband, Paul Pelosi, was the victim of a politically motivated assault that left him with a fractured skull.
Glenn Youngkin made a statement about the assault on Nancy Pelosi's husband while campaigning for a Republican congressional candidate.

Glenn Youngkin stated, "Speaker Pelosi’s husband – they had a break-in last night in their house, and he was assaulted. There’s no room for violence anywhere, but we’re gonna send her back to be with him in California. That’s what we’re gonna go do."
Virginia Democrats condemned Glenn Youngkin for choosing to speak against the Pelosis so soon after the attack.
When asked if he wanted to apologize for the comment, Glenn Youngkin chose not to do so.
Glenn Youngkin stated, "a terrible thing happened to the speaker’s husband and it should never have happened and we wish him a speedy recovery. The first lady and I keep him in our prayers."
